prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would. Let $p(x) = 2x - 7$ and $q(x) = 3x - b$.  If $p(q(4)) = 7$, what is $b$?
solution: Since $q(4) = 3\cdot 4 - b = 12-b$, we can write $p(q(4)) = 7$ as $p(12-b) = 7$.  Since $p(x) = 2x-7$, we have $p(12-b) = 2(12-b) - 7 = 17 - 2b$. Substituting this into $p(12-b) = 7$ gives $17-2b =7$, from which we have $b = \boxed{5}$.
gpt_response: Okay, so we have this thing called p(x) and q(x). p(x) equals 2x minus 7, and q(x) equals 3x minus b. Now, we need to find out what b is when we plug 4 into q(x) and then put that answer into p(x). So we have p(q(4)) equals 7. We need to figure out what b is to make that true. Let's try solving it together!
solution_prompt: Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 5?: Okay, so we have this thing called p(x) and q(x). p(x) equals 2x minus 7, and q(x) equals 3x minus b. Now, we need to find out what b is when we plug 4 into q(x) and then put that answer into p(x). So we have p(q(4)) equals 7. We need to figure out what b is to make that true. Let's try solving it together!
